statement:
If $f(x)$ is a polynomial over a ring with identity, then $x-a$ is a
factor if and only if $a$ is a root (that is, $f(a)=0$).

This theorem is of great help for finding factorizations of higher
degree polynomials. As example, let us think that we need to factor the
polynomial $p(x)=x^3+3x^2-33x-35$. With some help of the rational root
theorem we can find that $x=-1$ is a root (that is, $p(-1)=0$), so we
know $(x+1)$ must be a factor of the polynomial. We can write then
$$p(x)=(x+1)q(x)$$ where the polynomial $q(x)$ can be found using long
or synthetic division of $p(x)$ between $x-1$. In our case
$q(x)=x^2+2x-35$ which can be easily factored as $(x-5)(x+7)$. We
conclude that $$p(x)=(x+1)(x-5)(x+7).$$
